field_edited_text.value:
68 PaTarsco RivEr CROSSING

Street the center line was surveyed on Quail Street all the way to an inter-
section with the Philadelphia Road at Erdman Avenue. On this alignment
complete topography and profile was taken for the entire distance.

BORINGS

The State Roads Commission obtained from the Pennsylvania Railroad
Company boring data from borings made by the Railroad between the
years 1908 and 1913, for a crossing of the Patapsco River proposed by the
Railroad Company thirty years ago. The Railroad Company had at that
time selected a site for their crossing within a short distance of the site
proposed for this highway crossing. In fact, the proposed Railroad cross-
ing was only 110 feet from the proposed crossing at the north end and 50
feet at the south end. The borings made at that time were supplemented
by additional borings made in August, 1938 by the State Roads Com-
mission, for the purpose of checking the original data secured from the
Railroad Company, and for the additional purpose of securing undisturbed
samples for the determination of soil characteristics with particular respect
to the effect the soil conditions will have upon the cost of the tunnel con-
struction, and also with respect to the requirements for Bridge foundations.
The undisturbed samples taken by the State Roads Commission this year
were taken in sealed cylinders 3 inches in diameter and 12 inches long, at
frequent intervals, one in the location of the deepest mud area, and the
others in the locations of the main channel piers of the proposed bridge.

The results of the borings at this site show that a tunnel can be con-
structed without undue expense, and with comparatively little risk of
construction difficulties, and show also that bridge foundations at this site
present no unusual or difficult construction conditions.

FOUNDATIONS

The main section of the Patapsco River Crossing consists of 6790 feet of
through truss spans supported by steel bents and towers on concrete piers.
There are 14 piers in this group. Piers Numbers 1, 11, 12, 13 and 14 are
on shore and piers 2 to 10 inclusive are in the Patapsco River. Piers
Numbers 7 and 8 support the main cantilever span over the channel.

Soundings in the Patapsco River show water depths not over 40 feet and
sub-strata as shown by the borings on Plates 28 to 31 inclusive, indicate
that foundation conditions are favorable to the use of a standard type of
pler construction consisting of tremie concrete seals encasing steel bearing
